title: 103_hr4962
content: The "Coeur d'Alene Basin Restoration Act of 1994" is cited in this section as the Act's short title. It amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act by adding a Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference. Establishment of the Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference to develop a pollution prevention and restoration plan. Membership includes representatives from the EPA, Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, and Idaho Department of Environmental Quality. Steering committee to appoint management and technical advisory committees. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference will appoint advisory committees and develop a pollution prevention and restoration plan within a year of enactment. The Plan will include representatives from various entities and focus on water pollution control in the basin. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference will appoint advisory committees and develop a pollution prevention and restoration plan within a year of enactment. The Plan will clarify duties, describe funding methods, and incorporate environmental management concepts from State and Federal plans. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference will develop a pollution prevention and control strategy, including public review and approval processes for the plan. The State of Idaho draft plan will be approved by the Administrator if it meets the requirements. Upon approval, the plan will be considered an approved management program and a comprehensive conservation and management plan. Grant assistance may be provided to water pollution control agencies. Grants are provided to water pollution control agencies for assisting in the development of the Plan, with a federal share not exceeding 70% of the costs. Non-Federal sources must provide the remaining share, which can include in-kind services. The Administrator may set terms and conditions for the grants. The Administrator may establish terms and conditions for grants, with non-Federal sources providing the remaining share, which can include in-kind services. The definition of "Coeur d'Alene Basin" is specified, and the section does not affect the jurisdiction or powers of any department or agency. Authorization is given to the Environmental Protection Agency to receive necessary appropriations for fiscal years 1995-1999 for activities related to the Coeur d'Alene Basin. Authorization is given to the Environmental Protection Agency for activities related to the Coeur d'Alene Basin. Federal program coordination is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the United States Geological Survey, universities, and research institutions, will develop an integrated geographic information system for the Coeur d'Alene Basin. They will also upgrade recording sites to continuous monitoring stations with full gauging capabilities. The Secretary of the Interior, in collaboration with various entities, will convert partial recording sites in the Coeur d'Alene Basin to continuous monitoring stations with full gauging capabilities. Additionally, they will establish new monitoring stations for data collection and monitoring purposes, including groundwater mapping and water quality assessment. The Wildlife Management Cooperative and the Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference will establish a fisheries restoration program and conduct a wildlife species and habitat survey in the area. The Wildlife Management Cooperative and the Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference will establish a fisheries restoration program and conduct a wildlife species and habitat survey in the area. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to carry out activities related to improving the health of fishery resources, endangered species, migratory nongame species, and national resources plan species in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to improve fishery resources, conduct investigations, disseminate information, and survey habitats in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 1995-1999 to carry out these activities. SEC. 4. RESTORATION PLAN. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Bureau of Land Management, will cooperate with other natural resource trustees to develop a restoration plan for public lands in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, including creating a geographical information system inventory of mining sites and contaminated areas. The restoration plan for public lands in the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes audits of mining sites, cleanup of contaminated areas, stream and river restoration plans, monitoring of restored areas for effectiveness. The plan includes monitoring restored areas, developing a land management plan with various agencies, creating a geographical information system, and collaborating with the Forest Service and Fish and Wildlife. The plan aims to ensure coordinated management within the Basin, develop wildlife and fishery habitat management plans, monitor wildlife management areas, and create an integrated public recreation management plan. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities related to data collection, inventory of mining waste source areas, contaminated lands, resource information management, restoration activities, and monitoring data to achieve the goals of the integrated public recreation management plan in the Basin. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to carry out activities related to data management of resource information, restoration activities, acquiring mining contaminated lands for restoration, design and maintenance of restoration projects and management facilities, overseeing construction of repositories for mine waste, lake and river information program, long-term restoration and land management plans, and providing maintenance of restored public lands. Authorization of Appropriations: The Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management, is authorized to receive necessary appropriations for fiscal years 1995-2002 to carry out activities related to data management, restoration of contaminated lands, and long-term maintenance of restored public lands. SEC. 5. EXEMPTION FROM CERCLA LIABILITY. The EPA and DOI are exempt from liability under CERCLA for actions taken under this Act.
